questions.question: Act I provides basic information about the characters and their situation. This is called?

choices.answer: the drama
the turning point
the climax
the exposition

questions.question: In Act I, Scene i, why do Flavius and Marullus try to stop the people from celebrating?

choices.answer: the celebration disrepects the feast of Lupercal
they resent the fact Caesar defeated and murdered Pompey
Caesar will be offended by the manners of the crowd
Caesar will be embarrassed by all the attention paid to him

questions.question: In Act I, Scene ii, what warning does a soothsayer give?

choices.answer: beware a date in March
beware of Brutus, his friend
beware of his wife, Calpurnia
beware of plotters in his midst

questions.question: In Act I, Scene ii, why does Cassius flatter Brutus?

choices.answer: He fears Brutus may try to kill him
He need Brutus to support his plot against Caesar
He wants Brutus to leave Rome so Caesar will retire
He wants Brutus to marry his daughter in March

questions.question: What internal conflict does Brutus face in Act I?

choices.answer: He is Caesar's friend but does not want to live under a king
He is Caesar's enemy but agrees with Cassius about Caesar
He wants to be king but doesn't want to hurt Caesar
He wants to be king but doesn't want to offend Cassius

questions.question: According to Cassius, who is to blame for Caesar's rise to power?

choices.answer: destiny, which no one can avoid
Caesar's own mad desires
Romans like Cassius and Brutus, who do nothing to stop him
Inferior people like Flavius and Marullus

questions.question: What do Flavius and Marullus do in Act I, Scene i that ultimately get them killed?

choices.answer: plot to kill Caesar
drive of the common people who are celebrating on a work day
tear down decorations that honor Caesar
warn Caesar to beware the ides of March

questions.question: Why does Caesar distrust Cassius?

choices.answer: He is lazy and daydreams too much
He is powerful and owns too much land
He talks too much and is too eager to please
He thinks too much and is too clever

questions.question: According to Casca, how did Caesar react when offered the crown?

choices.answer: He rejected it 3 times but really wanted to accept it
He accepted it 3 times but really wanted to reject it
He rejected it twice but finally accepted it
He accepted it but only because Calpurnia would get one, too

questions.question: In Act I, Scene iii, when Casca describes the storm, why is he afraid?

choices.answer: He is afraid of being hit by lightning and killed
He is worried the storm is really the sound of fighting
He is afraid the gods are angry & something bad will happen
He is afraid Caesar is angry & will blame him for the storm

questions.question: Why does Cassius believe that Brutus should be part of the plot against Caesar?

choices.answer: People fear Brutus and will not challenge him
People respect Brutus and will accept what he does
Brutus is the strongest man in Rome, including Caesar
Brutus is the smartest man in Rome, except Cassius

questions.question: In Act I, Scene ii, what is suggested by the soothsayer's warning and Cassius' actions?

choices.answer: Brutus will be exiled
Flavius will be arrested
Caesar will be overthrown or killed
Calpurnia will have a child

questions.question: What does Cassius do in his conversation with Brutus in Act I, Scene ii?

choices.answer: He praises Caesar in order to win Brutus' support
He flatters Brutus in order to win Brutus' support
He insults Brutus in order to make him angry
He questions Brutus in order to understand Caesar

questions.question: In Act I, Scene ii, why does Cassius describe his memory of swimming with Caesar?

choices.answer: to show that Caesar is weak and afraid
to show that Caesar is sincere and proud
to show that Caesar is kind and gentle
to show that Caesar is cruel and mean

questions.question: When Caesar says that Cassius has a "mean and hungry look," what feeling is he expressing?

choices.answer: friendship
pity
suspicion
admiration

questions.question: Based on Brutus' reaction to Cassius, what may be Brutus' tragic flaw?

choices.answer: He may be too suspicious
He may be too brave
He may be too cowardly
He may be too trusting

questions.question: At the end of Act I, Scene ii, what plan does Cassius describe?

choices.answer: a plan to trick Brutus by writing fake letters
a plan to trick Caesar by pretending to serve him faithfully
a plan to gather an army against Caesar
a plan to encourage Casca to persuade Caesar to reign

questions.question: Based on statements made in Act I, what can you infer the Roman attitude toward suicide to be?

choices.answer: It was against the law and public opinion
It was a mortal sin and offensive to God
It was an honorable alternative to disgrace
It was a cowardly solution to one's problems

questions.question: Judging from his actions in Act I, what may be Caesar's tragic flaw?

choices.answer: He is too weak and trusting of others
He is too ambitious and overconfident
he is not shrewd or smart enough
He is not proud or strong enough

questions.question: Which character stated this quote from Act I?

choices.answer: Caesar
Cassius
Antony
Brutus

questions.question: Which character stated this quote from Act I?

choices.answer: Caesar
Antony
Calpurnia
Casca

questions.question: Which character stated the following from Act I?

choices.answer: Antony
Casca
Caesar
Cassius

questions.question: Who said, "Beware the ides of March"?

choices.answer: the soothsayer
Cassius
Brutus
Antony

questions.question: Why did Caesar ask Antony to touch Calpurnia during the race for the feast of Lupercal?

choices.answer: He felt that it would make the people like her more
It was an acknowledgement of her as queen
It meant that Antony would win the race
He thought it would cure her infertility

questions.question: What was the feast of Lupercal?

choices.answer: a festival honoring Zeus
a festival celebrating Caesar's defeat of Pompey
a festival honoring women
a fertility festival honoring the founding of Rome
